Petitioner.</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: center; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">-Versus-</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Government of Bangladesh and others</span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">. . . Respondents.</span></strong> </span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: right; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 9pt;">In W.P. No. 10929 of 2014; W.P. No. 9934 of 2015</span></em></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: center; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">With</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Southeast University</span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: right; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">. . . Petitioner.</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: center; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">-Versus-</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Government of Bangladesh and others</span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">. . . Respondents.</span></strong> </span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 9pt;">In W.P. No. 11840 of 2015</span></em></strong></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Articles 58D (repealed) and 102</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Admittedly, the caretaker government as contemplated  by virtue now repealed 13<sup>th</sup> Amendment to the Constitution was created </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">for the purpose of holding free and fare election</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> amongst political parties in Bangladesh, the tenure of the said government being 90 days. By virtue of the provisions under Article 58D of the then Chapter-IIA of part IV of the Constitution, the Caretaker Government was only authorized to do routine works. However, in some cases, the said Caretaker Government, which functioned for about two years, admittedly transgressed their constitutional perimeter by acting beyond </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">their jurisdiction and authority.</span></strong> <strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">However, while</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> the said Caretaker Government, under the Constitution, was at all authorized to continue for such a long period of two years beyond the mandate of the Constitution is another hot issue to be determined by this Court in a proper case, it cannot be submitted reasonably by the Government side that a decision like imposition of tax on private universities and creation of classification between private and public universities in respect of tax liabilities was part of routine works of the then Caretaker Government. . . . (37 and 39)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Article 102</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">When the private universities were established</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> by virtue of the Act of 1992, they were, from the very beginning, enjoying such tax exemption. The Philanthropists or the Trusts which contemplated at the relevant time to establish such private universities in order to fill up the gap created by the lack of public universities did also have legitimate expectation that such private universities would be tax free universities.          . . . (41)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Articles 83 and 102</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">When the tax can only be imposed by or under the authority of an Act of parliament by virtue of Article 83 of the Constitution, an un-elected Caretaker Government under no circumstances can impose such tax on the private universities or higher education in the garb of technically using the word “re-fixation” or “reduction” from general rate. Therefore, this Court is of the view that, the </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">said SROs, namely SRO Nos. 156 and 158 of 2007</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> suffered from the following improprieties from the beginning:</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 24.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(a) they were not in any way related to the holding of national election, </span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 24.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(b) </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">decisions to withdrawn tax exemption</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> from private universities and thereby to impose tax thereon were major policy decisions and as such were not part of routine works of the then caretaker government as mandated by the then relevant provisions of the Constitution and that-</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 24.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(c) they were not that urgent decision that the caretaker government could not wait for the elected government to take such policy decision.</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Accordingly, the said impugned SROs of 2007 were issued in clear violation of the mandate of the Constitution insofar as the same related to the functions of the Caretaker Government and, thus, the same were ultra vires the then relevant provisions of the Constitution. . . . (42)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Articles 27, 31 and 102</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">When the said majority number of students have been compelled to study at private universities at high cost because of the lack of sufficient number of public universities with almost free education therein, the classification created by the government in <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">between public and private universities inso</span></span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">far as the tax liabilities are concerned cannot</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> be said to be reasonable classification. Yes, Private Universities are of different class altogether. But, are the students therein different? The answer is ‘No’. They all are our children having equal right to education and entitled to equal protection of law as those of Public Universities as guaranteed under Articles 27 of the Constitution.  No such reasonable nexus is apparent from the said SROs. Thus, such discrimination is clearly hit by Articles 27 and 31 of the Constitution. It is rather unfortunate that when a non-elected Caretaker Government (widely known as army backed government) imposed such tax liability in 2007 on the said private universities and thereby put more hindrances to the smooth education of the students of middle class and families of limited means, the elected government in 2010 has followed of the same course hoodwinking the Legislature and did not even place this issue before the elected members of the Parliament.        . . . (45)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Articles 27, 31 and 102</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Discrimination as regards tax liabilities between</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> private and public universities being a major policy decision, and imposition of tax on private universities, in whatever names (reduction or re-fixation), being a major political policy decision, it should have been placed before the Parliament for the view of the elected M.Ps. However, the government has apparently issued the said SRO in 2010 in the same mechanical terms as used in the SROs issued by the nonelected Caretaker Government in 2007. Therefore, this Court is of the view that, this classification is unreasonable classification in the facts and circumstances and background of the cases .It has already been noticed that, by issuing the said SRO No. 268 in 2010, the government even technically imposed general rate of tax @35% on the public universities. This reveals that even the concerned officials of the government did not apply their minds in drafting or in issuing the impugned SRO No. 268 dated 01.07.2010. On this ground as well, this SRO of 2010 should be knocked- down.  . . . (46)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Articles 27, 31 and 102</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Creating discrimination between the private universities and public universities as well as between their students, insofar as tax liabilities are concerned, is a major political policy decision and as such the same must be placed before Parliament for seeking opinion of the elected representatives of the people of this country. The same having not been done before issuing the impugned SROs, they should be knocked-down on the </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.2pt;">principle that the delegatee-government acted</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> beyond the power of delegation.  ...(47)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Articles 15, 17, 27, 31, 32 and 102</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In view of the said fundamental principles of State policy as enunciated under Articles 15 </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">and 17 as well as the fundamental right to life</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> as </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">guaranteed under Article-32 of the Constitution</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">and the </span></span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">unreasonable discrimination between private</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> and public universities being hit by Articles 27 and 31 of the Constitution and the lack of  delegatee-government’s power to issue the impugned SROs, we find merit in the Rules and as such the same should be made absolute.                                           . . . (54)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 112%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 112%;">Pirzada Syed Sariatullah and others Vs. Government (Writ Petition No. 2207/2008;</span></em></strong> <strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 112%;">Unni Krishnan, J.P. Vs. State of A.P., AIR 1993 S.C. 2178; Chameli Singh and others Vs. State of U.P, AIR1996 S.C. 1051; Manzil Morshed Vs. Bangladesh and others, 15 BLC (2010)-351; NBR Vs. Advocate Zulhas Uddin Ahmed and others, 18 BLC (AD)-52;</span></em></strong> <strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 112%;">Kudrat-E-Elahi Vs. line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 9pt; line-height: 110%;">(In Writ Petition No. 3371 of 2015)</span></em></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. S. Rashed Jahangir, D.A.G with</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Ms. Mahfuza Begum, AA.G. with </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Pratikar Chakma, A.A.G with </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Ms. Shuchira Hossain, A.A.G</span></p><p> </p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; text-align: right; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">. . .<u>For the respondent No.3</u> </span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 9pt; line-height: 110%;">(In W.P. Nos. 9562 of 2008, 9564 of 2008, 9566 of 2008, 9567 of 2008, 12558 of 2012, 8985 of 2010 and 2110 of 2013)</span></em></span></p><p> </p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 150%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 150%;">JUDGMENT</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 23.75pt; line-height: 115%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Sheikh Hassan Arif, J</span></u></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">, </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Since the questions</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;"> of law and facts involved in the aforesaid writ petitions are almost same, they have been taken up together for hearing, and are now being disposed of by this single judgment. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">2.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Rules in the aforesaid three bunch of writ petitions were basically issued in two fold terms, namely</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">,</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> calling upon the respondents including the government of Bangladesh to show cause as to why the SRO No. 156-Ain/Aikor/2007 dated 28.06.2007 and SRO <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">No. 158-Ain/Aikor/2007 dated 28.06.2007 issued</span> by the government under Section 44(4) (b) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 1984 withdrawing the tax exemptions in favour of the petitioner <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">universities/educational institutions and thereby</span> imposing 15% tax on their income relating to assessment years 2008-2009 to 2010-2011 and as to why the SRO No. 268-Ain/Aikor/2010 dated 01.07.2010 issued by the government under the same provisions purportedly re-fixing the tax payable by the said petitioners at the rate of 15% in respect of assessment years 2011-2012 and onwards should not be declared to be without lawful authority and are of no legal effect and as to why the respective assessment orders, followed by demand notices as well as notices demanding advance taxes from them pursuant to the said SROs, should also not be declared to be without lawful authority. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">3.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">SHORT  BACKGROUND FACTS:-</span></u></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Short facts, relevant for the disposal of the Rules, are as follows:-</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l14 level1 lfo3; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(a)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">   </span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">First Bunch of </span></u></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">W</span></u></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">rit Petitions: </span></u></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">North South University (NSU)</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> filed five writ petitions (Writ Petition Nos. 9562, 9563, 9564, 9566 and 9567 of 2008), <strong>University of Asia Pacific (UAP)</strong> filed three writ petitions (Writ Petition No. 1131 of 2009, Writ Petition No. 1969 of 2009 and Writ Petition No.5176 of 2010) and <strong>some other universities</strong> filed some other writ petitions (Writ Petition Nos. 2682 of 2016, 13246 of 2015 and 12885 of 2015) calling in question the said <u>SRO No. 156 and SRO No. 158 both dated 28.06.2007</u>, concerned assessment orders and demand notices demanding advance taxes pursuant to the said SROs.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; mso-list: l14 level1 lfo3; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">(b)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">   </span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Second Bunch of Writ Petitions: </span></u></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">North South University (NSU)</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> filed four writ petitions (Writ Petition No.11545 of 2015, Writ Petition No. 11546 of 2015, Writ Petition No. 8507 of 2010 and Writ Petition No. 987 of 2011), <strong>International University of </strong></span><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Business Agricultural and Technology</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> (IUBAT)</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> filed eight writ petitions (Writ Petition No.6861 of 2012, Writ Petition No. 12558 of 2012, Writ Petition No. 2110 of 2013, Writ Petition No.5793 of 2014, Writ Petition No. 5794 of 2014, Writ Petition No. 5795 of 204, Writ Petition No. 10769 of 2014 and  Writ Petition No. 9733 of 2015), <strong>University of Asia Pacific</strong> filed 3 (three) Writ petitions (Writ Petition No. 3423 of 2012, Writ Petition No. 986 of 2011 and Writ Petition No. 4878 of 2013),   <strong>Ahsanullah University of Science &amp; Technology (AUST)</strong> filed one writ petition (Writ Petition No.8985 of 2010), <strong>University of Science and Technology, Chittagong (USTC)</strong> filed one writ petition (Writ Petition No.10847 of 2015), and <strong>some other universities</strong> filed some other writ petitions (Writ Petition Nos. 3371 of 2015, 2510 of 2015, 1891 of 2015, 8697 of 2011, 6177 of 2013, 11195 of 2014, 8930 of 2011, 3681 of 2013, 3682 of 2013, 6404 of 2014, 4048 of 2013, 4049 of 2013, 4050 of 2013 and 14609 of 2012) calling in question the legality of the aforesaid <u>SRO No. 268 dated 01.07.2010</u>, by which the earlier <u>SRO No. 158 dated 28.06.2007</u> was repealed by the government and thereby tax @ 15% was imposed on the private universities and colleges <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">except the public universities. They also</span> challenged the concerned assessment orders, demand notice demanding </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">advance tax as well as they sought refund of advance tax for some income years and not to deduct tax on FDR and also sought relief against account freezing.   </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l14 level1 lfo3; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(c)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Third Bunch of Writ Petitions</span></u></strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">: </span></u></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Some universities including the World University filed some writ petitions (Writ Petition Nos. 11840 of 2015, 10929 of 2014, 8187 of 2015 and 9934 of 2015) calling in question the legality of both sets of SROs, namely <u>SRO Nos. 156 and 158, both dated 28.06.2007</u> and <u>SRO No. 268 dated 01.07.2010</u> as well as proceedings against them for alleged tax evasion and demand of advance tax.</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">4.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Supplementary Rule: </span></u></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In Writ Petition Nos. 9563 of 2008, 9562 of 2008, 9564 of 2008, 9565 of 2008, 9566 of 2008, 9567 of 2008 and 1131 of 2009, it was further stated by the petitioners that as per Order No.2 dated 11.01.2007 (Gazetted on 13. 01. 2007) passed by the Hon’ble President  under Article 141 C (1) of the Constitution, the hearing of all cases relating to enforcement of fundamental rights was suspended till the Emergency was lifted. Thus, since the petitioners filed the said writ petitions during the period of emergency, they could not invoke fundamental rights under Articles 26, 27, 31 and 32 read with Articles 15, 17, 19 and 83 of the Constitution of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh. Hence, the Petitioner (North South University) in Writ Petition No. 9563 of 2008 and the Petitioner (University of Asia Pacific) in Writ Petition No. 1131 of 2009 obtained supplementary Rules from this Court  invoking the issue of violation of fundamental rights by the said SROs and impugned actions of tax authorities pursuant to the same.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.2pt;">Petitioners’ Descriptions (deduced from</span></u></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> their petitions):</span></u></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">The <strong>North South University</strong>, as petitioner, altogether filed Writ Petition Nos. 9562 of 2008, 9563 of 2008, 9564 of 2008, 9566 of 2008, 9567 of 2008, 8507 of 2010, 987 of 2011, 11545 of 2015 and 11546 of 2015 stating, amongst others:</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l11 level1 lfo2; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">i)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">That the North South University (NSU)</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;"> is founded by North South University Foundation (hereinafter also referred to as the “said foundation”). The said Foundation is a charitable organization set up for the promotion of education as incorporated under the Societies <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Registration Act, 1860. The Foundation</span> was registered on 13-05-1992. Under the said Act of 1860, the Foundation cannot act on commercial basis. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l11 level1 lfo2; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">ii)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">That the petitioner (NSU) is the first generation Private University in Bangladesh and was established by a group of philanthropists, industrialists, bureaucrats and academics. The Government of Bangladesh approved the establishment of the petitioner in the year 1992 under the then Private University Act, 1992. The University follows the American system with all <span style="letter-spacing: -0.2pt;">its distinctive features, semesters, credit</span> hours, letter grades, one examiner system and so on. Its curricula, when first introduced, were reviewed by relevant departments of the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, and University of California at Berkeley, USA. The academic programs are continually updated and adapted to meet the local needs with international standard.    </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l11 level1 lfo2; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">iii)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">That the petitioner (NSU) is accredited <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">by the University Grants Commission of</span> Bangladesh (UGC), the accreditation authority of the Ministry of Education, Government of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh. It is recognized by many world-class universities of USA, UK, Canada, Australia, India, China, South Korea and Malaysia. The credits <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">obtained at NSU (petitioner) are accepted</span> in most of the respectable universities of USA, Canada, Australia and other countries. Petitioner’s graduates have <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">been accepted in the Graduate programs</span> of Harvard, Cornel, University of Pennsylvania, and other well-known universities. Graduates of the petitioner are studying for higher degrees at the <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">York University, Canada, with Scholarship</span> provided by York University. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l11 level1 lfo2; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">iv)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">That the petitioner (NSU) maintains academic collaboration with many foreign universities. Notable among those universities are (1) St. Xavier University, Chicago, USA; (2) Indian University of Pennsylvania, USA; (3) Luton University, UK; (4) University of Delwaware, USA; (5) University of Maryland, USA; (6) Quest University, Canada; (7) Yunnan University, China; (8) Multimedia University, Malaysia; (9) Wayne State University, USA; (10) <span style="letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">University of South Australia, Australia,</span> and (11) Kyung Hee University, South Korea. The petitioner has also research <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">collaborations with world class research</span> institutes, such as International Center for Diarrhoeal Diseases Research (ICDDRB), Dhaka in its various academic programs in Biotechnology, Microbiology and Public Health.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 4.5pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">         </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">The <strong>University of Asia Pacific (UAP),</strong> as petitioner, altogether filed writ petition Nos. 1131 of 2009, 1969 of 2009, 5176 of 2010, 986 of 2011, 3423 of 2012 and 4878 of 2013 stating, inter-alia, that:</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l16 level1 lfo4; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">i)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">the petitioner (UAP) is founded by the University of Asia Pacific Foundation (hereinafter also referred to as the “said Foundation”). The said Foundation is a charitable company set up for the promotion of education as incorporated <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">under Section 28 of the Companies Act,</span> 1994 and as such the said Foundation cannot act on commercial basis. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l16 level1 lfo4; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">ii)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">the petitioner (UAP) is also the first generation Private University in Bangladesh and was established by a group of philanthropists, industrialists, bureaucrats and academics. The Government of Bangladesh, through the Ministry of Education, approved the establishment of the petitioner in the year 1992 under the then Private University Act, 1992 (as amended). At present, Dr. Jamilur Raza Chowdhury is the Vice Chancellor of the University of Asia Pacific. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l16 level1 lfo4; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">iii)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">The petitioner (UAP) is accredited by the University Grants Commission of Bangladesh (UGC). Its curricula have been approved by the University Grants Commission (UGC) and the Government of Bangladesh. Presently, it is offering Undergraduate program in 9 (nine) disciplines and 6(six) Graduate Programs. Academic programs are conducted on semester basis. Senior faculty members of the petitioner-university are with Ph.D./MBA/MSS from renowned universities of USA, UK, Canada, Australia and other developed countries. The academic programs of the petitioner (UAP) are continually updated and adapted to meet the local needs with required international standard.    </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">The <strong>International University of Business</strong></span><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> Agriculture and Technology (IUBAT),</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> as petitioner, altogether filed Writ Petition Nos. 6861 of 2012, 12558 of 2012 ,  2110 of 2013 , 5793 of 2014, 5794 of 2014, 5795 of 2014, 10769 of 2014 and  9733 of 2015 stating, inter-alia, that:<u> </u></span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l19 level1 lfo5; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">i)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">the petitioner (IUBAT) is the first private university in Bangladesh and was founded by Prof. Dr. M. Alimullah Miyan, ex Director of the Institute of Business Administration, Dhaka University. The Petitioner submitted a formal representation to the Ministry of Education, Government of Bangladesh on 27.07.1989 for the establishment of a non-profitable private university. In fact, private universities in Bangladesh are the brain-child of Prof Dr. Mian who worked relentlessly with the concerned Government agencies for establishing private universities in Bangladesh. He gave his invaluable support and experiences of different counties to the Government for the enactment of the Private Universities Act, 1992. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l19 level1 lfo5; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">ii)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">the petitioner (IUBAT) is geared to effectively contribute to agro-economic, technological and social development of Bangladesh. The aim is to promote higher professional education with relevance to those growth areas of the economy with required qualified human resources and create a climate of professionalism and scholasticism to promote further development of the society. The petitioner (IUBAT) honestly believes that the fundamental economic problems of the society can be tackled by people through an investment in human resources development and in the process of promoties self reliance in agro-economic development and higher education in the field of science and technology. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 105%; mso-list: l19 level1 lfo5; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">iii)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">the petitioner (IUBAT) started its activities before the enactment of the Private University Act 1992. When the petitioner submitted its proposal to the Ministry of Education for obtaining no objection for establishing the said University on July 27, 1989, the petitioner (IUBAT) clearly stated the objects of the said University including its non-profitable nature in the following terms :</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in .25pt 6.0pt .75in;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">“IUBAT shall be a non-profitable, non-Government autonomous organization with its own charter and regulations and shall be sponsored by the human development society which is a duly registered NGO”.</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l19 level1 lfo5; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">iv)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">in the proposal forwarded by the petitioner (IUBAT) to the Ministry of Education it was also clearly mentioned that it was to be operated under a non profit foundation type of concept outside the influence of the existing institutions as well as outside the influence of vested groups. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 105%; mso-list: l19 level1 lfo5; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%; color: black;">v)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%; color: black;">that having regard to the proposal of the petitioner (IUBAT), the Ministry of Education vide its letter dated <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">12.09.1991 also recognized the University</span> as a non-profit private university/ institution in collaboration with its foreign Universities. The Ministry of Education further, by its letter dated 27.10.1992, asked the University to comply with its activities in terms of the Private University Act, 1992. Finally, after complying with the provisions of the Private University Act, 1992, the Ministry of Education vide its letter dated 07.08.1998 formally approved the Petitioner University under the Private University Act, 1992. After the enactment of the Private University Act in 1992 and its amendment in 1998, the petitioner (IUBAT) started its academic journey. Its Degree programs started in 1992 in <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">collaboration with Assumption University,</span> Bangkok, Thailand.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.2pt;">The <strong>Ahsanullah University of Science &amp;</strong></span><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> Technology (AUST),</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> as petitioner, filed writ petition Nos. 8985 of 2010 stating that:</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">the petitioner No.1, Ahsanullah University of Science &amp; Technology <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">(AUST), is a private university founded</span> and sponsored by the Dhaka Ahsania Mission. The petitioner No.1 provides education for undergraduate and post-graduate level at a reasonable cost characterized by academic excellence in a range of subjects that are particularly relevant to the present and anticipated needs of the Country. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 105%; mso-list: l18 level1 lfo6; tab-stops: list .25in; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%; color: black;">iii)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%; color: black;">petitioner No. 1 (AUST) is a non profit, non-sectarian private university specialized on engineering and science based education. The aim of the petitioner No.1 is to provide students with opportunities, resources and expertise to achieve academic excellence with a stimulating and supporting environment. It is the premier centre of excellence in science, engineering and technology by creating and transferring knowledge with human touch to the young generations for enhancing the quality of life in Bangladesh and beyond. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l18 level1 lfo6; tab-stops: list .25in; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">iv)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">Petitioner No.2 is Mr. Md.
