line-height: 110%; color: black;">19.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">Common Case of the Petitioners:</span></u></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">It is commonly stated by the petitioners that, since inception they have been enjoying exemption from paying income tax on the surplus income generated by them by virtue of an S. R.O. being <u>S.R.O No.454-L/80 dated 31<sup>st</sup> December, 1980</u> issued by the Government (Ministry of Finance) under section 60(1) of the then Income Tax Act, 1922 which, vide its Clause (a) (3), exempted the universities and other non-profitable educational institutions from payment of income tax. That during the course of their such enjoyment of exemption, the Government issued another S. R. O., being <u>S.R.O No.178-Income Tax/2002 dated 3<sup>rd</sup> July,2002,</u> under Section 44 (4) (b) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 1984 substituting the above Clause-(a) (3)  in that such exemption would continue only in respect of universities who were not operated commercially.</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">20.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">It is further stated that, the said S.R.O. No. 178 dated 3<sup>rd</sup> July, 2002 did not make any material difference from the former S.R.O No. 454 dated 31<sup>st</sup> December 1980 in so far as exemption from payment of income tax by the petitioners were concerned in that the earlier S.R.O was applicable to non-profitable universities and other educational institutions and the latter became applicable to the universities and educational institutions which were operated on non-commercial basis and as such the intention and object of both the S.R.Os were same. Thus, it is stated, the petitioners remained entitled to get exemption from income tax under the said S.R.O. dated 3<sup>rd</sup> July, 2002 as the petitioners could not in any case run their universities on commercial basis as per their own charters.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">21.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">It is further stated that, the petitioners being a non-profitable institutions do not operate commercially and the whole income of <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">the petitioners are applied for imparting education</span> as per the objects of their Society/Charter/ Foundation/Trust. No part of the income of the petitioners are consumed/utilized by the members of the said Foundation /Society /Trust/ Non - Commercial University. But the same are utilized solely for the purpose of education and diffusion of knowledge which is absolutely non-commercial in nature. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">22.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">However, it is stated, by two impugned S.R.O.s being, S<u>.R.O. No.156-Ain/Aikor/2007 dated 28.06.2007</u> and <u>S.R.O. No.158-Ain/Aikor/2007 dated 28.06.2007</u>, the then Non-Party Caretaker Government promulgated/issued new provisions regarding tax on the surplus income of universities purportedly under Section 44(4)(b) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 1984 and thereby cancelled the exemption of taxes which they were entitled to by the earlier <u>S.R.O. No. 454-L/80 dated 31<sup>st</sup> December,1980 </u>and <u>S.R.O No. 178 dated 3<sup>rd</sup> July, 2002</u>.  </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">23.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">It is stated that, vide impugned <u>S.R.O. No. 158 dated 28.06.2007</u>, Non-Party Caretaker Government (the Ministry of Finance) for the first time made division between Public Universities and Private Universities with an additional proviso and thereby imposed / re-fixed 15% tax on Private Universities. Finally, it is stated,   the Government (the Ministry of Finance) vide impugned <u>S.R.O. No. 268 dated 01.07.2010</u> introduced a new provision under section 44(4)(b) of the Income-tax Ordinance, 1984 which virtually imposed wholesale tax @ 15% on private universities irrespective of its nature whether it is run non-commercial basis or imparting education on medical science or engineering or imparting education in other fields including on information technology. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">24.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Common grievance of the petitioner Universities are that, pursuant to the aforesaid impugned S.R.Os, the tax exemptions as enjoyed by them have been withdrawn without lawful authority, taxes have been collected from them illegally and they have been illegally asked to pay advance taxes and/or arrear taxes vide different impugned memos issued by the concerned tax authorities. Being aggrieved by the said impugned SROs as well as the impugned actions of the respondents pursuant to the said SROs, the petitioners moved this Court and obtained the aforesaid Rules. At the time of issuance of the Rules, this Court, vide different ad-interim orders, either stayed operation of the impugned SROs or stayed such demand of tax issued by the respondents on the petitioners or proceedings that followed (as the case may be).    </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">25.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Rules have been opposed by the Government by filing affidavit-in-oppositions in Writ Petition Nos. 9562 of 2008, 9564 of 2008, 9566 of 2008, 9567 of 2008. 12558 of 2012, 8985 of 2010 and 2110 of 2013, though the case of the respondent- government is common in all the writ petitions.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">26.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">SUBMISSIONS:</span></u></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Rafiq-ul-Huq (learned senior counsel), Mr. A.F. Hassan Ariff (learned senior counsel), Mr. Omar Sadat, Mr. Shakhawat Hossain, Mr. Hassan M.S. Azim, Kazi Akhter Hossain, Ms. Rabeya Jamali, Mr. Ashik Al Jalil, MR. Ashikur Rahman and Ms. Mehran Morshed, learned advocates, have made the following common submissions on behalf of the petitioner universities: </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">1)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">That the petitioner-universities have been established under trust deeds or instruments in accordance with the provisions under Private University Act 1992 and/or 2010. According to the said trust deeds as well as the instruments by which they have been created, they are not profitable organizations. Since no income from the universities are pocketed by the trustees or any other individuals, the income of the universities cannot be termed as income from business or profession within the meaning of the Income Tax Ordinance, 1984 and as such the same cannot be taxed in accordance with the provisions under Article 83 of the Constitution read with the provisions of the Income Tax Ordinance, 1984. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">2)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">That the petitioners, from the very beginning, have enjoyed tax exemption by virtue of SRO No. 454-L/80 dated 31-12-1980, and, on the basis of such exemption, the petitioner-universities were established in Bangladesh in order to impart higher education to the young citizens of Bangladesh as the government or the State has failed to provide adequate facilities to all students in Bangladesh who are aspiring for higher education or tertiary education. This being so, the petitioner-universities have acquired a vested right to run their institutions without payment of tax. However, the government having for the first time in 2007 introduced tax on them and not on public universities, the same is without lawful authority and is of no legal effect in-as-much as that the same has created discrimination within the same class of higher educational institutions viz-a-viz their students by <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">creating sub-classes therein unreasonably</span> which is in violation of the fundamental rights of the students of the said universities under Article 27 as well as Article 31 of the Constitution.  </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">3)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">That since the tax exemption as enjoyed</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> by the petitioners was arbitrarily withdrawn vide impugned SRO No. 156 dated 28.06.2007 and 15% tax was imposed by virtue of impugned SRO No.158 dated 28.06.2007 on some private universities and colleges except the public universities, the said SRO No. 158 dated 28.06.2007 has further <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">created sub-classifications among private</span> universities or private educational <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">institutions by providing tax exemptions</span> to the colleges imparting education in medical, dental, engineering and ICT. This being so, such unreasonable sub-classifications should also be declared to be without lawful authority.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">4)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">That the exemption having been withdrawn in 2007 and the tax having been imposed  @ 15% for the first time in 2007 by an unelected caretaker government, the same is without lawful authority and ultra vires the then Article 58D of the Constitution of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh in as much as that withdrawal of exemption of tax in respect of students of private universities and colleges and thereby imposition of tax on their institutions were major policy decisions and the same could not be taken by such an unelected caretaker government in view of the provisions constituting such non-party caretaker government. In this regard, learned advocates have referred to an unreported decision of <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">this Court in <strong>Pirzada Syed Sariatullah</strong></span> <strong>and others vs. Government</strong> (Writ Petition No. 2207/2008). </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Further referring to the SRO No. 158 dated 28.06.2007, learned advocates submit that since some universities imparting educations in Medical, Dental, Engineering and ICT have been exempted along with the public universities, the said SRO also cannot pass the test of reasonableness and as such the same is hit by Articles 27 and 31 of the Constitution of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh. Learned advocates for some of the universities have further submitted that, though their universities were imparting educations in Medical, Dental, Engineering and ICT, still they were issued demand notices demanding arrear tax or advance taxes at the relevant time pursuant to the said SRO No. 158 dated 28.06.2007.    <strong> </strong></span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 105%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">6)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">That right to life as guaranteed under Article 32 of the Constitution being included therein  the right to medical care, education etc., without which a life of human being will not be life in true sense, by putting hindrances on such right to life of the students of the said private universities by imposing tax on their education system, the impugned SROs have clearly violated the provisions under Article 32 of the Constitution. In this regard, they have referred to some decisions of the Indian Supreme Court and our jurisdiction, namely <strong>Unni Krishnan, J.P. v. State of A.P., AIR 1993 S.C. 2178, Chameli Singh and others v. State of U.P, AIR1996 S.C. 1051, Manzil Morshed vs Bangladesh and others, 15BLC (2010)-351, NBR vs. Advocate Zulhas Uddin Ahmed and <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">others, 18BLC (AD)-52 etc</span></strong><span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">. According</span> to the petitioners, since right to life guaranteed in a civilized society implies the right to food, water, decent environment, education, medical care etc,. with the passage of time, these rights have in the meantime become inseparable ingredients of right to life and as such the right to life as guaranteed under Article 32 of our Constitution implies that such life has to be a life in a civilized society having <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">right to food, water, decent environment,</span> education, medical care and shelter. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">7)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Further referring to the provisions under</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Articles 15 and 17 of our Constitution wherein imparting education has been contemplated as one of the basic principles of the State Policies, learned advocates submit that, while interpreting the provisions under the said SROs as well as the provisions of the Constitution, in particular Articles 27, 31, 32 under Part-III and Article 83 thereof, the said principles of State policy under Part-II should be kept in mind and should be the basis of such <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">interpretation as the same is the mandate</span> of Article-8 of our Constitution.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">8)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Learned Advocates further submit that, since the State has admittedly failed to provide sufficient educational Institutions for their young citizens and such admitted failure has basically <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">allowed emergence of private Universities</span> in Bangladesh by virtue of Private University Act, 1992 giving them full tax exemption like public universities and thereby allowing the students  belonging to middle class and families of limited resources in Bangladesh to attend those private universities at their own expenses without any subsidies or help from the government, picking up the private universities for imposition of tax by virtue of the impugned SROs is not only unreasonable but lacks any reasonable nexus in particular when imparting free education has been repeatedly emphasized in our Constitution under Articles 15, 17 and 19 of Part-II and impliedly under Article 32 of Part-III. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">9)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Further referring to different commentaries</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> including some observation of late Mr. Mahmudul Islam in his book, <strong>Constitutional Law of Bangladesh, Third Edition,</strong> as well as the observation of their Lordships Mr. Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed and Mr. Justice Mustafa Kamal, as they then were, in <strong>Kudrat-E-Elahi Vs. Bangladesh, 44 DLR (AD)</strong>, learned advocates submit that, in the said case, the fundamental principles of State policy as incorporated under Part-II of the Constitution have been given effect to while determining a case relating to local government institution, namely Upazilla Parishad, and thereby our Apex Court has interpreted   the provisions of Article 59 of the Constitution in line with the fundamental principles as enunciated under Articles 9 and 11 of the Constitution. This being so, according to them, this Court should also interpret the provisions of the impugned SROs, as well as the provisions of Articles 27, 31 and 32 in the facts and circumstances of the present case in line with the said fundamental principles as incorporated in Articles 15 and 17 of the Constitution. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">10)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">  </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Further referring to the provisions under Article 83 of the Constitution and Section 44(4)(b) of the Income <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Tax Ordinance, 1984. learned advocates</span> submit that, Chapter-VI of the said Ordinance being titled “Exemptions and Allowances” and the heading of Section 44 being “Exemption”, Clause-(b) of sub-section (4) of Section 44 cannot be given effect to by the said impugned SROs if, by virtue of the said SROs, tax burden of  the universities is increased in any way. According to them, since the said entire Chapter-VI, in particular clause (b) of sub-section (4) of Section 44, deals with exemption, reduction in rate or other modification in respect of tax, the government cannot impose tax on the private universities by saying that the tax has been re-fixed inasmuch as that the word “ other modifications” as occurring in Clause (b) of sub-section (4) of Section 44 must be read in accordance with the spirit and connotations as generated by the preceding words “exemption” and “reduction in rate” in view of the principle of <strong>ejusdem generis</strong>. Therefore, according to them, since the government, by the said SROs, have in fact imposed tax burden on the petitioners, it has violated the said principle of <strong>ejusdem generis</strong> and as such the said SROs cannot stand in the eye of law. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">11)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">  </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Further referring to Article 83 of the Constitution and Section 44(4)(b) of the said Ordinance, learned advocates submit that, the government having been delegated with the power of reduction, exemption and modification by virtue of Section 44(4)(b) of the said Ordinance, it acted  beyond the said authority of the parent law by imposing taxes on the petitioners by virtue of the said SROs and as such acted beyond the power of delegatee. In this regard, they have referred to the test of delegated legislation as narrated by Mr. Mahmudul Islam in his book  <strong>Constitutional Law of Bangladesh, Third Edition (P-503)</strong> upon referring to different authorities and three-fold test as narrated by Lord Diplock in <strong>Eldowney vs. Fords, (1969) 3 WLR 179, </strong>which is as follows: </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 105%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 48.25pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">“first, determine the meaning of the words used in the Act of Parliament itself to describe the subordinate legislation which that authority is authorised to make, secondly, to determine the meaning of the subordinate legislation itself and finally, to decide whether the subordinate legislation complies with that description.</span></em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">” [Para 11, at page 254]. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">12)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">  </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Learned advocates further submit that, the impugned SROs suffer  from malice in law in that the same have taken away the vested right of the petitioners to enjoy tax exemption in particular when by virtue of the provisions under the Private University Act, 2010, the petitioners are not allowed to make any profit for the personal gains of their trustees or founders and that they are prevented by Section 9(3) of the said Act even from mortgaging their land and structure in favour of any bank or financial institutions. This being so, according to them, since the private universities have been picked up for imposition of tax without any reasonable basis, such actions of the respondents cannot stand in the eye of law inasmuch as that such withdrawal of tax exemption is clear violation of provisions under Section 21 of the General Clauses Act. In this regard, they have referred to the cases in <strong>Enamul Haq (Md) vs. Jatiyo Bishwabiddalay and others, 59 DLR-556, Azizuddin Industries vs. Government of Pakistan, 18 DLR-92 and Chief Controller of Imports and Exports vs. Hussain Ali Shah A. Fazlani, PLD 1960 SC-310</strong>. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l20 level1 lfo17; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">13)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">  </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Learned advocates finally submit that, when the petitioner universities have taken up responsibilities to fulfill the obligations of the State in imparting higher education to its citizens and thereby saving huge foreign currency by preventing the students of Bangladesh from going abroad for such higher education, they are in fact entitled to different incentives from the government like the garment industries in Bangladesh, as, according to them, though the garment industries are <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">earning foreign currencies, the petitioners</span> are preventing foreign currencies from leaving Bangladesh and thereby they are also contributing to the national exchequer. This being so, according to them, instead of providing any sort of incentives in favour of the petitioners, the government, vide the impugned <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">SROs, have provided some disincentives</span> and hindrances in the running of those universities.  </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">27.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">As against above submissions, Mr. S. <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Rashed Jahangir, learned Deputy Attorney General </span>appearing for the respondent-government, has made the following submissions. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo18; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">a)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">That the general rate of tax as applicable to the private universities was @ 37.5% before and at present it is @ 35%. This being so, by virtue of those impugned SROs, tax liabilities of the petitioner universities have been reduced to 15%. Thus, according to him, the said SROs do not in any way violate the provisions of Clause (b) of sub-section (4) of Section 44 of the said Ordinance. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo18; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">b)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Learned DAG further submits that, though the said Universities were given tax exemption at the beginning by virtue of SRO No. 454-L/80 dated 31.12.2008, such exemptions have gradually been withdrawn by the government as because with the passage of time the private universities in Bangladesh have improved to a great extent and as such it has been considered by the government that they should now pay tax on their surplus income.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo18; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">c)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Further referring to the SRO Nos. 156 and 158, both dated 28.06.2007, learned DAG submits that, while the tax exemption enjoyed by the petitioners previously was withdrawn by the said SRO No. 156, general rate of tax at the rate of 37.5% or 35% became applicable on the petitioners on the very day on which the said tax exemption was withdrawn. Therefore, when, by virtue of the next SRO No. 158 dated 28.06.2007, 15% tax was re-fixed, this re-fixation of tax at the rate of 15% cannot be termed as imposition of tax on the petitioners inasmuch as that the same was apparently a reduction from general rate of 35%. However, in the course of such submission, learned DAG has frankly admitted that such general rate of tax at the rate of 37.5% or 35% was never applied to any universities in Bangladesh or even before creation of Bangladesh.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 105%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo18; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">d)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">As regards the issue of caretaker government’s authority to issue the said two SROs in 2007, learned DAG submits that the concerned caretaker government remained in power for about two years and they promulgated two national budgets during the said period. This being so, to fulfill the requirement of those budgets, taxation in fact became a routine work of the said caretaker government and as such the said caretaker government was entitled to issue the said SROs in 2007 by virtue of which the tax exemption of the petitioners was withdrawn and, at the same time, reduced rate of tax @ 15% was refixed on them. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 105%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo18; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">e)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">As regards submissions of the petitioners regarding the provisions under Articles 15 and 17, namely the fundamental principles of State Policy as provided under Part-II of the Constitution, learned DAG submits that it has been decided in <strong>Kudrat-E-Elahi case</strong> in clear terms that the fundamental principles of State Policy under Part-II of the Constitution are not judicially enforceable and as such, according to him, the petitioners have no case under Articles 15 and 17 of the Constitution. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo18; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .75in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">f)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">       </span></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">As regards petitioners submissions of acquiring vested right of exemption, leaned DAG submits that, it is the mandate of Section 21 of the General Clauses Act that the authority or person who can promulgate something can also withdraw or re-fix the same and as such the petitioners cannot claim any such vested right  against their obligation to pay statutory tax. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .25in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">28.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">  </span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">DELIBERATIONS OF THE COURT:</span></u></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">To appreciate the submissions of the learned advocates as well as the relevant provisions of law, let us first start with the examination of the concerned SROs including the impugned SROs chronologically with the reproduction of the relevant parts of the same.</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l3 level1 lfo19; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">A)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">          </span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">SRO No. 454-L/80 dated 31.12.1980:-</span></u></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">No. S.R.O. 454-L/80.-In exercise of the powers conferred by sub-section (1) of Section 60 of the Income tax Act, 1922 (XI of 1922) and supersession of the Ministry of Finance Notification No. S.R.O. 1041(K)/61, dated the 31<sup>st</sup> October, 1961 the Government is pleased to direct that:</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo20; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">a)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">the <u>following classess of income shall be exempt from the tax payable</u> under the said Act and they shall not be taken into account in determining the total income of an assessee for the purposes of the said act.-……………………… … ………………………</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l12 level1 lfo21; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(3)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">   </span></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The income of a university or other educational institution existing <u>solely for educational purposes and not for purposes of profit;</u></span></span></p><p> </p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .25in;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">(Underlines supplied) </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 4.5pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">29.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">     </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">It appears from this SRO that, in exercise of power under Section 60(1) of the then Income tax Act, 1922, the government exempted tax liability of universities and other educational institutions, irrespective of private or public, which were existing solely for educational purposes and not for purposes of profit. Therefore, it can be said that the educational institutions that existed at the relevant time were generally exempted from payment of tax and that also included therein the schools and colleges in addition to universities. The admitted position is that, at that time, there was no such private universities in Bangladesh. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l3 level1 lfo19; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">B)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">     </span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">SRO. No. 178-Aikor/2002 dated 03.07.2002.</span></u></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 48.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Gm, Avi, I bs 178-</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">‡</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">aÑ</span></strong> <strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">¢ejÀl¦f</span></strong> <span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">sub-clause <strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;">(3) </strong></span><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">fË¢aØq¡¢fa</span></strong> <strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">nB‡e, </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">kb¡x-</span></strong></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 18.6pt; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 48.0pt;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -.3pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">(3) the income of any university,</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;"> or any other educational institution, <u>which is not operated commercially</u> and also medical college, dental college, engineering college and institution imparting education on information technology;”</span></p><p> </p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 66.6pt;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">(Underlines supplied) </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 4.5pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">30.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">     </span></span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">This SRO in fact has not made any material change as tax exemption remain</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">ed</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;"> applicable if the university or educational institution in question was not operating commercially. However, while in SRO No. 454 dated 31.12.1980 the government used the words “existing solely for educational purposes and not for purpose of profit” as the qualification for getting such tax exemption, it used the words “which is not operated commercially” vide the above quoted SRO of 2002. Therefore, practically the impact remained almost same in so far as the petitioners’ tax liabilities were concerned. It may be noted in this regard that, a Full Bench of this Court, in <strong>Income Tax Reference Application Nos.159-162 of 2011 and 511 of 2004</strong>, <strong>reported in 20 BLC(2015)-457</strong>, has already examined the purport of the said words “not operated commercially” as was occurring in SRO No. 178 of 2012 and held that the said words being vague, the benefit would go in favour of the assessee-private universities. Be that as it may, this SRO does not have any considerable impact on the merit of the instant writ petitions.</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; mso-list: l3 level1 lfo19; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">C)<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">    </span></span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">SRO No. 156-Ain/Aikor/2007 and SRO No. 158-Ain/Ainkor/2007, both dated 28.06.2007:</span></u></strong></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">31.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">It appears that, by this SRO No. 156 of 2007, the </span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">G</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">overnment has withdrawn the said tax exemption in a whole sale manner by deleting the sub-clause (3) of the earlier SRO No. 454-L/80 dated 31.12.1980 and, on the same day, issued another SRO No. 158 dated 28.06.2007 imposing 15% tax on the private universities which were approved by the University Grand Commission. However, while imposing such 15% tax, the government used the words </span><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">“</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">f¤ex ¢edÑ¡le L¢lm</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">”</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">. Interestingly, by this SRO No. 158 of 2007, some private colleges and Universities imparting education in Medical, Dental, Engineering and ICT have also been exempted from such liability of Tax along with the public universities, though they were made required to submit tax returns. </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">32.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Therefore, it further appears that, by this SRO No. 158 of 2007, the Government has for the first time created a division between universities and colleges in Bangladesh in so far as their tax liabilities were concerned in that the Public Universities have been kept tax exempted as before and the tax became payable by the private universities. Not only that, a sub-division has also been created among the private universities and colleges in that the private universities and colleges which impart education in Medical, Dental, Engineering and ICT have become only liable to submit tax returns but remained exempted from payment of tax. </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l3 level1 lfo19; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">D)<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">    </span></span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">SRO No. 268-Ain/Aikor/2010 dated 01.07.2010:</span></u></strong><u></u></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Gm, Avi, I bs 268-AvBb/AvqKi/2010</span></strong> <span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Income Tax Ordinance</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">, </span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">1984</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;"> (</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Ord. No. XXXVI of 1984</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">) </span><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">By this SRO, according to the words used therein, the tax liabilities of all private universities and colleges have been reduced to 15% (“</span><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">fË­</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">‡</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">cu BuL</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">‡</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">­ll q¡l qÊ¡p L¢lu¡ 15% ¢edÑ¡le L¢lm</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">”) </span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">by repealing</span> <span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">the earlier SRO No. 158-Ain/Aikor/2007 dated 28.06.2007. Most interestingly, though the Public Universities have been kept away from the application of this tax liability @ 15%, the tax exemption as enjoyed by the said public universities has also been impliedly cancelled by this SRO. Therefore, not only the private universities and colleges became liable to pay tax at the rate of 15%, the public universities in fact became liable to pay tax at the general rate, namely @ 37.5% or @ 35% with effect from 1<sup>st</sup> July, 2010. Surprisingly, this withdrawal of tax exemption of public universities has only been cancelled very recently in 2015 vide Finance Act, 2015 by incorporation of a Clause in the Sixth Schedule to the Income Tax Ordinance, 1984. This reveals the sheer no-application of mind by the concerned government officials who drafted and issued this SRO. When the public universities have admittedly never been required to pay tax till date,<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>legally their tax exemption was in fact repealed or withdrawn in 2010 by virtue of this SRO No. 268 dated 1<sup>st</sup> July, 2010 as this SRO apparently repealed the earlier SRO No. 158 dated 28.06.2007.</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">34.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">With the above picture of the concerned SROs including the impugned SROs, let us now address the issues raised by the learned advocates in these writ petitions. </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">35.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Issue of Caretaker Government:</span></u></strong></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Admittedly, the caretaker government as contemplated<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>by virtue now repealed 13<sup>th</sup> Amendment to the Constitution was created for the purpose of holding free and fare election amongst political parties in Bangladesh, the tenure of the said government being 90 days. By virtue of the provisions under Article 58D of the then Chapter-</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">II</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">A of part IV of the Constitution, the Caretaker Government was only authorized to do routine works. However, in some cases, the said Caretaker Government, which functioned for about two years, admittedly transgressed their constitutional perimeter by acting beyond their jurisdiction and authority. This issue came up for consideration by this Court in some cases including in unreported Writ Petition No. 2207 of 2008 (<strong>Pirzada Syed Sariatullah and others vs. Government</strong>), wherein an amendment to <span style="letter-spacing: -.3pt;">the Muslim Marriages and Divorce (Registration)</span> <span style="letter-spacing: -.3pt;">Act, 1974 vide Muslim Marriages and Divorces</span> (Registration) (Amendment) Ordinance, 2008 <span style="letter-spacing: -.4pt;">(promulgated by the said Caretaker Government)</span> was under challenge. This Court, in the said case, categorically held that the Caretaker Government was not authorized or empowered by the Constitution to act anything which did not come under their authority which was necessary for running of the affairs of the government at the relevant time for holding free and fare election. In this regard, the Court observed as follows: </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiBold; mso-ansi-language: EN;">""</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Dc‡ii Av‡jvPbv nB‡Z Avgv‡`i wbKU cÖwZqgvb nq †h t </span></strong></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">cÖ_gZt </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Muslim Marriages and <span style="letter-spacing: -.4pt;">Divorce (Registration) (Amendment)</span> Ordinance, 2008 </span><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">(2008 m‡bi 3bs Aa¨v‡`k) (G¨v‡bKPvi-G) RvZxq wbe©vPb msµv</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">wZ nB‡e bv;</span></u></strong></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">GgZ</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiBold; mso-ansi-language: EN;">¡</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">” </span></strong></p><p> </p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .75in;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">(Underlines supplied)</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">36.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Therefore, the basic tenor of the said judgment of this Court is that the Caretaker Government should have waited for the elected government to take any major policy decisions as that was the mandate of the Constitution. </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">37.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">In the cases before us, the admitted position is that, the government, for the first time in 2007, by virtue of the impugned SRO Nos. 156 and 158, imposed a tax liability on some of the private universities and colleges. Not only that, for the first time a distinction was created as regards tax liability between public universities and private universities. It is true, as submitted by the learned DAG, that practically since the said Caretaker Government promulgated two budgets, it became necessary for them to do some taxation works. However, while the said Caretaker Government, under the Constitution, was at all authorized to continue for such a long period of two years beyond the mandate of the Constitution is another hot issue to be determined by this Court in a proper case, it cannot be submitted reasonably by the Government side that a decision like imposition of tax on private universities and creation of classification between private and public universities in respect of tax liabilities was part of routine works of the then Caretaker Government. </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l4 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">38.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Admittedly, the creation of private universities was due to the failure of the government to provide sufficient educational<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>facilities for higher education. The preamble of now repealed “</span><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">­hplL¡l£ ¢hnÄ¢hcÉ¡mu BCe, 1992</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">” </span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">is quoted below for the purpose of understanding the real intent of the Legislature for enacting the said law: </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN;">“</span><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">­</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">k­</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">‡</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">qa¥ ®c­n EµQ ¢nr¡l H²jhdÑj¡e Q¡¢qc¡ f§lZ J hÉfL pÇfÐp¡lZ, <u>phÑp¡d¡l</u></span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt;
