text-align: right;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">...Petitioners.</span></em></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">-Versus-</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Infrastructure Development Company Limited UTC Building , (Level-16), 8, Panthapath, Kawranbazar, Dhaka-1215  and others.</span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">... Respondents</span></em></strong></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Artha Rin Adalat Ain (VIII of 2003)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 12</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">From a perusal of provisions in Section 12 of the Ain, it appears that though there is a provision for selling the mortgaged property before filing of the suit the said provision of Section 12(3) of the Ain is not mandatory, it is directory. It is in this Court’s view that non-compliance of the provisions of section 12 of the Ain cannot be a bar in instituting a suit in the Artha rin Adalat for recovery of </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">loan against the borrower and the guarantor.</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> In the event of noncompliance of section 12(3) of the Ain an alternative provision has been provided in section 12(6) and as such the ground taken by the Petitioner is not at all sustainable in la     . . . (8)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Artha Rin Adalat Ain (VIII of 2003)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 7(3)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">From a plain reading of the provision of section 7(3) of the Ain is also not mandatory. Moreover, in the present case as it appears from the Orders sheet the present Petitioner as Defendant appeared in suit and took time to file written statement more than once. Therefore, ground of not-compliance of the provisions relating to service of summons is not at all entertainable at this stage as the petitioners by their act and conduct have waived the said irregularities whatever in service of summons.        . . . (9)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Article 102</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">It is true that the powers conferred upon the High Court under Article 102 of the Constitution are discretionary in nature which can be invoked for the enforcement of any fundamental right or legal right but not for mere asking of it particularly in view of the existence of efficacious alternate remedy. The constitutional Court should insist upon the party to avail of the same instead of </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">invoking the extraordinary Writ Jurisdiction</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> of the Court. It is the duty of the Court to see that alternate remedy is first followed.      ...(14)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Article 102</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">This Court in the exercise of its Writ Jurisdiction is not required to sit on qppeal over the Judgment and Decree of the Artha Rin Adalat unless it could be shown that the </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Adalat had acted without jurisdiction or made</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> any finding upon no evidence or without considering any material evidence/ facts or that it had acted mala fide or in violation of any principle of natural Justice.   . . .(15)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Article 102</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Under Article 102 since its inception it has been recorded that the sound and settled principle of law is that wherever alternate </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">and efficacious remedy is available it</span></strong> <strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">should be availed of before Writ Jurisdiction is sought to be exercised.</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;"> In our opinion therefore,</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> this Rule Nisi is liable to be discharged for </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">availability of alternate remedy of appeal.    . . . (16)</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"> </span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Lindsay Petroleum Company Vs. Prosper Armstrong Hurd, (1874) 5 PC 221; Md. </span></em></strong><strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">Shahabuddin Khan Vs. Bangladesh, represented</span></em></strong><strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> by the Secretary Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs and others, 28 BLD (HC) 294; Shitalakhaya Ice and Cold Storage Pvt. Ltd. Vs. Artha Rin Adalat No.1, Dhaka and others, 64 DLR 487; Zahirul Islam Vs. National Bank Limited and others, 46 DLR (AD), 191; Gazi M.Towfic Vs. Agrani Bank and others, 54 DLR (AD) 6 and Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation Vs. Artha Rin Adalat and others, 59 DLR (AD) 6 ref.</span></em></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Khandaker Mahbub Hossain  with</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. M.Taha Molla                 </span></p><p> </p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">...For the Petitioners.</span></em></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Mr.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> Md.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> Mizanur Rahman Khan</span></span></p><p> </p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">... For Respondent No.1</span></em></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Khan Mohammad Shameem Aziz with</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Wayesh Al- Haroni and</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Mohammad Bulbul Ahmed</span></p><p> </p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">... For the Respondent No.3.</span></em></strong></span></p><p> </p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 150%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 150%;">JUDGMENT</span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 10.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 24.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mahmudul Hoque,J: </span></u></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In this application under Article 102 of the Constitution the Rule Nisi was issued calling upon the Respondents to show cause as to why the impugned proceeding in Artha Rin Suit No. 63 of 2011 disposed of exparte on 27.6.2013 by Judge , Artha Rin Adalat No.4, Dhaka (Annexure-L) should not be declared to have been passed without lawful authority and is of no legal effect and/or pass such other order or further order or orders as to this Court may seem fit and proper. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 30.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">2.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">              </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Facts relevant for disposal of this Rule, in brief, are that the  Respondents Bank as Plaintiff instituted  Artha Rin Suit No. 63 of 2011 for recovery of Tk.18,25,21,844.00  against the present Petitioners and others  in the Artha Rin Adalat No.4, Dhaka stating ,inter alia,  that at the request of the defendant No.1 company  the plaintiffs financial institutions  collectively sanctioned a term loan of Tk.11,35,00,000.00 to the Defendant No.1 company against various Securities out of which the Defendants enjoyed and availed of Tk= 11,21,47,500/-. As per terms of the facility agreement the principal amount to be paid by 18 quarterly  instalments  of Tk.62,30,417 each with effect from  15.3.2007. The Defendants having failed to pay the outstanding instalment, requested the Plaintiffs for restructuring  the <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">existing repayment arrangement and accordingly</span> rearrangement was done by mutual agreement on 6.9.2007. As per said arrangement the principal instalments to be repaid by 21 quarterly instalments of Tk. 56,80,263/- with effect from on 15.6.2008.  But the Defendants again failed to repay the outstanding dues. For such failure of the Defendants the outstanding dues stood at Tk.12,55,15,946.00. Inspite of repeated  demands made by the Plaintiffs, the Defendants  failed to liquidate the outstanding  liability, resultantly said liability of the Defendants stood at Tk.18,25,21,844.00 as on 15.3.2011. The Plaintiffs instituted the instant Artha Rin Suit  against the Defendants  for recovery of the said loan. Before filing of the suit the Plaintiffs  tried to sell the mortgaged property through auction but failed  because of the property mortgaged with the Plaintiffs are lease hold property. </span></span></p><p> </p><h2 style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-style: normal;">3.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-weight: normal; font-style: normal;">The Defendant No.3 contested the suit by filing written statement and the Defendant No.2 though appeared in suit ultimately did not file written statement and contested the suit. The Artha Rin Adalat heard the suit and decreed the same against the Defendant No.3 on contest and ex parte against  the other Defendants by its  Judgment and Decree dated 27.6.2013. It is further stated that the Petitioner no. 2 was not aware of the filing of Artha Rin Suit No. 63 of 2011 as there was no service of summon upon him. The Petitioner came to know about the Impugned Judgment and Decree  on 30.7.2013 and on search it has come to the notice of the Petitiners that the Respondents Bank obtained the decree by suppressing summons and without compliance of the provisions contained in Sections 7 and 46 of the Ain and in connivance with the Defendant No.3 in suit. At this stage the Petitioner moved this Court challenging the validity of the Judgment and Decree passed in Artha Rin Suit No. 63 of 2011 by filing this application and obtained  the present Rule and Order of Stay. </span></span></h2><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">4.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The Respondent Nos. 1 and 3  contested the Rule. Among them only Respondent No.1 filed an Affidavit-in-Opposition  denying all the material allegations made in the writ petition contending, inter alia, that the Petitioner No.1 company obtained a term loan  from the Plaintiff financial institutions and failed to make payment of the said loan as per terms and conditions of the agreement. Inspite of repeated request and demand made by the Respondent-Bank, the Petitioner and others having failed to pay the outstanding dues, the Respondents as Plaintiffs instituted Artha Rin Suit against the Petitioners and others for recovery of the loan  and the said Suit was decreed on contest against the Defendant No.3 and ex parte against other defendants in suit. The Petitioner No.2 appeared in the suit and took several adjournments for filing written statement but ultimately did not file written statement and refrained himself from contesting the suit for the reason best known to him. It is also stated that the statements made in the writ petition are incorrect, misleading and misinterpretation of law and facts. It is also stated  that the Plaintiffs at the time of filing of the Suit submitted talabana (requisites) for the purpose of service upon  the defendants as per provisions of law and alternatively published notice in the Dailies as  per provisions of Section 7 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 (“Ain”). There was no violation of any provisions of law as alleged by the Petitioners and the Artha Rin Adalat upon compliance of necessary provisions of law and procedure legally decreed the suit and it is open for the Petitioner as Defendants in suit to prefer appeal against the Judgment and Decree of the  Artha Rin Adalat under Section 41 of the Ain. Since there is provision of appeal against the Judgment and Decree of the Artha Rin Adalat  the instant Writ Petition is not maintainable  in law and as such the Rule Nisi is liable to be discharged. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Khandaker Mahbub Hossain, Senior Advocate with Mr. M.Taha Molla, the learned Advocate appearing for the Petitioners submit that the Bank as Plaintiff instituted the suit without selling the mortgaged property under Section 12 of the Ain, as such the suit is not maintainable in law. It is also argued that the plaint in suit was not presented upon compliance of section 7(3) of the Ain enclosing a proforma notification to be published  in the dailies as such the suit was filed in violation of the said provision of the Ain. Mr. Hossain further submits that the suit was not filed within  the time fixed under Section 46 of the Ain, as such the suit was barred by limitation . Finally Mr. Hossain submits that the Artha Rin Adalat in passing the Impugned Judgment and Decree acted mala fide and passed the Impugned Judgment and Decree in violation of law and principle of natural Justice. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Md. Mizanur Rahman with Mr. Md. Bulbul Ahmed, the learned Advocates appearing for the Respondent Nos. 1 and 3 respectively submit that the plaint in suit was filed upon compliance of the provisions of the Ain and there was no violation of any provisions of law and as such the allegation of the Petitioners regarding service of summons  and non-compliance  of provision of law is untrue, mis-leading and wholly misconceived. Referring to the Orders Sheet  of the Artha Rin Suit No. 63 of 2011 Mr. Mizanur Rahman submits that it would be evident from the orders that the summons were duly served upon the Petitioner No.2 who appeared in suit  as recorded in Order No. 4 dated 23.8.2011. It is also argued that the present Petitioner No.2 as Defendant No.2 in suit sought time to file written statement by filing applications on 24.10.2011 and 23.11.2011 and the said applications were allowed by the Adalat with costs. It is also submited that the Adalat referred the matter for mediation but the mediation process failed. Thereafter, the Adalat framed issues and proceeded with the hearing and finally decreed the suit against the Defendants and as such there was no violation of any provision of law. Mr. Rahman finally submits that there is an efficacious remedy in the form of appeal for the present Petitioner under Section 41 of the Ain against the Judgment and Decree  of the Artha Rin Adalat. But the present Petitioners without taking recourse under Section 41 of the Ain  moved before this Court by filing  this  Writ Petition  under  Article 102 of the Constitution of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh and as such the present Writ Petition is not maintainable in law.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Heard the learned Advocates for the parties, perused the application, Supplementary Affidavit, Affidavit-in-Opposition and the annexures annexed thereto.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In the instant Rule the Petitioner firstly raised  a question that the Plaintiffs  have filed the Artha Rin Suit for recovery of the loan  without  compliance  of the provisions as contained in Section 12  of the Ain which provides that the financial institutions  shall not file suit for recovery of the loan without selling the mortgaged property and making adjustment of the sale proceeds  with the claim or taking any step to sell the mortgaged property. From a perusal of provisions in Section 12 of the Ain, it appears that though there is a provision for selling the mortgaged property before filing of the suit the said provision of Section 12(3) of the Ain is not mandatory, it is  directory. It is in this Court’s view that non-compliance of the provisions of section 12 of the Ain can not be  a bar in  instituting a  suit  in the Artha Rin Adalat for recovery of loan against the borrower  and the gurantor. In the event of  non-compliance of Section  12(3) of the Ain an alternative provision has been provided in Section 12(6) and as such the ground taken by the Petitioner is not at all sustainable in law. Secondly, the Petitioner raised  a question of non-supply of a proforma notice with the plaint in suit by the plaintiffs  at the time of filing of the suit under Section 7(3) of the Ain for the purpose of publication in the news paper. To appreciate the point raised, Section 7(3) of the Ain may be looked into  which runs thus:-</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;">7z pje S¡l£ pÇf¢LÑa ¢hd¡ex</span></strong></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;">(1).................................</span></strong></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;">(2).................................</span></strong></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;">(3) S¡a£u °c¢eL f¢œL¡u ¢h‘¡fe fÐL¡­nl j¡dÉ­j pje S¡l£l BN¡j hÉhÙÛ¡ ¢qp¡­h h¡c£ Bl¢S c¡¢M­ml pju Bc¡m­a Bl¢Sl p¢qa HL¢V ej¤e¡ ¢h‘¡fe c¡¢Mm L¢l­he, Hhw Bc¡ma f§hÑha£Ñ Ef-d¡l¡l ¢hd¡e Ae¤k¡u£ LlZ£u qC­m, Eš² ¢h‘¡fe¢V fÐ­u¡Se£u pw­n¡de h¡ f¢lhaÑe p¡­f­r, a¡vr¢ZLi¡­h S¡l£Ll­Zl ¢e¢jš fÐ­u¡Se£u hÉhÙÛ¡ L¢l­he z</span></strong></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">9.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">          <span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">  </span></span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">From a plain reading of the provisions  quoted above this Court finds that the aforesaid provisions in Sub-section 7(3) is also not mandatory. Moreover, in the present case as it  appears from the Orders sheet the present Petitioner  as Defendant  appeared in suit and took time to file written statement more than once. Therefore,  ground of non-compliance of the provisions relating  to service of summons is not at all entertainable at this stage as the petitioners by their act and conduct have waived the said irregularities whatever have had in the process of service of summons. In this regard the Case of Lindsay Petroleum Company Vs. Prosper Armstrong Hurd (1874) 5 PC 221 may be referred to, wherein Sir Barnes Peacock has observed that:</span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">“Where it could be practically unjust to give a remedy, either because the party has, by his conduct, done that which might fairly be regarded as equivalent to a waiver of it, or has by his conduct and neglect he has, though perhaps not waiving that remedy, yet put the other party in a situation in which it would not be reasonable to place him if the remedy were afterwards to be asserted in either of these cases, Lapse of time and delay are most material.”</span></em></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">10.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Thirdly, the Petitioner raised a point that the suit was not filed within one year from the date of default in payment of 10% of the loan amount by the borrower as per Section 46 of the Ain. In the case of Md. Shahabuddin Khan Vs. Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs and others reported in 28 BLD (HC) 294 and Shitalakhaya Ice and Cold Storage Pvt. Ltd. Vs. Artha Rin Adalat No.1, Dhaka and others reported in 64 DLR 487, it has been held that: </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">“the provisions of Section 46 of the Ain so far it relates to the question of filing the suit by the Bank or financial institution  against the borrower  within specified time  is  directory not at all mandatory. Therefore, in any view of the matter the suit is not barred by limitation and it can not be  equated with the analogy  of Section 28 of the Ain.” </span></em></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">11.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In view of the above, non-compliance of the provisions  of Section 46 it can not be  said that the suit is barred by limitation. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">12.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In the instant Rule the Petitioners challenged the validity and propriety of the Judgment and Decree passed by the Artha Rin Adalat in Artha Rin Suit No. 63 of 2011.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">13.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In the case of Zahirul Islam Vs. National Bank Limited and others reported in 46 DLR (AD), 191, Gazi M.Towfic Vs. Agrani Bank and others reported in 54 DLR (AD) 6, Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation Vs. Artha Rin Adalat and others reported in 59 DLR (AD) 6. It has been held that: </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">“Since special provisions for appeal has been made against the judgment  and decree passed by the Artha Rin Adalat no application under Article 102 lies against such  judgment and decree.” </span></em></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">“Therefore, the suit against the petitioner was barred by limitation and in excess of the Court’s jurisdiction  are matters to be agitated in appeal and not under the writ  jurisdiction.”</span></em><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> (Per Mustafa Kamal,J:)</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">14.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">It is true that the powers conferred upon the High Court under Article 102 of the Constitution are discretionary in nature which can be invoked for the enforcement of any fundamental right or legal right but not for mere asking of it  particularly in view of the existence of efficacious alternate remedy. The constitutional Court should insist upon the party to avail of the same instead of invoking the extraordinary Writ Jurisdiction of the Court. It is the duty of the Court to see that alternate remedy is first followed.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 105%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">15.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">This Court in the exercise of its Writ Jurisdiction is not required to sit on appeal over the Judgment and Decree of the Artha Rin Adalat unless it could be shown that the Adalat had acted without jurisdiction or made any finding upon no evidence or without considering any material evidence/facts or that it had acted mala fide or in violation of any principle of natural Justice.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 105%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">16.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">From the aforesaid discussion based on the Judgment of the Supreme Court it will be clear that through out during the subsistence of Article 102 since its inception it has been recorded that the sound and settled principle of law that whatever alternate and efficacious remedy available it should be availed of before a Writ Jurisdiction is sought to be exercised. In our opinion therefore, this Rule Nisi is liable to <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">be discharged for availability of alternate remedy</span> of appeal.  </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">17.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">In view of the decisions referred hereinabove the remedy lies for the Petitioner in appeal only as the grounds agitated in the instant Writ Petition are the matters to be looked into by the Appellate Court sitting in appeal. </span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">18.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">For the reasons stated hereinabove this Court finds no mala fide in the proceedings in Artha Rin Suit No. 63 of 2011 and in the Impugned Judgment and Decree passed by the Artha Rin Adalat No. 4, Dhaka and there was no violation of any principle of natural Justice calling for interference and as such we are inclined to discharge the Rule.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">19.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In the result, the Rule is discharged, without any order as to costs.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">20.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The Order of Stay granted at the time of issuance of the Rule is hereby recalled and stand vacated.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">21.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Communicate a copy of this judgment to the Court concerned.</span></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 150%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 150%;">Ed. </span></strong></span></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 105%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"> </span></p><p> </p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title=""><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10pt; line-height: 110%;">Writ Petition No. </span></strong></a><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10pt; line-height: 110%;">9126 of 2013.</span></strong></span></p></div></div><p> </p><p> </p></div></div>
528	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Saifuddin Murad Vs. The State 2017 (2) LNJ 1</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Case No:</b> Criminal Appeal No. 10074 of 2015 </p><p><b>Judge:</b>  Md. Rais Uddin. J.</p><p><b>Court:</b> High Court Division,</p><p><b>Advocate:</b> Mr. Abul Kalam Mainuddin, Mr. Shaiful Bashar Bhandary,</p><p><b>Citation:</b>  2017 (2) LNJ 1</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  2016</p><p><b>Appellant:</b>  Saifuddin Murad </p><p><b>Respondent:</b>  The State </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Criminal Law</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2017-08-14</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso Accused-Appellant </span></em></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 105%; margin: 0in -1.45pt 3.0pt -1.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">-Versus-</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: -.7pt; tab-stops: 15.95pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">The State </span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: -7.0pt; text-align: right;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">... Respondent</span></em></strong></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Arms Act (XI of 1878)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 21</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Bengal</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> Arms Act Manual, 1924</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Rule 74</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; letter-spacing: -.4pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Av‡Mœqv‡¯ªi jvB‡mÝ cÖ`vb, bevqb I e¨envi bxwZgvjv, 2016</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-ansi-language: EN;">bxwZ 29</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">From a combined reading of the above provisions of law, it is a clear proposition of law that the maximum amount of ammunition can be possessed during the year by the holder of a licence of Revolver and Pistol, 100 rounds bullets. The strict requirement of law is that onus lies on the prosecution to prove its case beyond all reasonable doubt. The learned Judge of the Special Tribunal failed to consider the above </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">provisions of law that the accused-appellant is</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> entitled to purchase 50 pieces of bullets at a </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">time and keep in his custody maximum 100 pieces</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> of bullets. In the instant case the prosecution </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">has found 98 pieces of bullets in the possession</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> of the accused-appellant which is not violation of provision of law under section 21 of the Arms Act, 1878 and as such the learned Judge of the Special Tribunal passed the impugned judgment and order of conviction is not sustainable in law.          . . . (29 and 30)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.4pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Abul Kalam Mainuddin, Advocate. </span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">. . . For the accused-appellant.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Shafiul Bashar Bhandary, D.A.G with</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Swapan Kumar Das, A.A.G. </span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; text-indent: -.5in; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">. . . For the State.</span></em></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 150%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 150%;">JUDGMENT</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 22.5pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Md. Rais Uddin, J. </span></u></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">This appeal is directed</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> against the judgment and order of conviction and sentence dated 18.11.2015 passed by the learned Metropolitan Special Tribunal No.6, Dhaka in Metropolitan Special Tribunal Case No. 300 of 2013 corresponding to G.R. Case No. 368 of 2013 arising out of Zatrabari Police Station Case No. 98 dated 28.04.2013  convicting the appellant under section 21of the Arms Act, 1878 and sentenced him to suffer  simple imprisonment for 1 (one) month with a fine of Tk. 100/- (one hundred) only in default to suffer simple imprisonment for 7(seven) days more. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">2.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The prosecution case, in short, is that one Sub-Inspector of police, namely, Md. Aslam Ali lodged a written ejahar with Zatrabari Thana at 11.15 a.m. on 28.04.2013 alleging inter alia that the informant with the help of Sub-Inspector/21936 Md. Hafizur Rahman, Constable/8331 Monir, Constable/19508 Billal arrested accused Saifuddin Murad son of Yousuf Harun and recovered from him (1) 1(one) pistol written on the body as READ MANUAL BEFORE USE PATEMTED BERETTA USA CORP ACKK, MD (2) 04 Mazgin  written as CAL. 7.65 M.M/32 Auto MADE IN ITALY, (3) total 98 (ninety eight) round Pistol Bullets out of which 72 round .32 bore and 20 round 7.65 bore and (4) 1(one) M.T. Cartridge with spot of firing pin in back side (5) 1(one) license of Pistol with Star mark written as No. 41/19/2009 MD. SHAIFUDDIN MURAD. In course of duty period in Thana he got information through wireless that one person was lying at Second Floor of a Multistoried building of Ibrahim, at 22/2/B Golapbag under Zatrabari Police Station with bullete injury. On hearing that he went there at once and came to know that injured person were taken away towards emergency department of Dhaka Medical College and Hospital. He duly informed the incident to the higher authority and went there  at Dhaka Medical College Hospital Morgue and found dead body of Morshed Kamal, son of late Hazi Bulu Miah. At that time accused was present with the victim and on query the informant came to know that victim died by bullet injury in his abdomen through licensed pistol of the accused. That at one stage of interrogation accused informed that Pistol kept at Second Floor Multi storied building of Ibrahim, situated at 22/2/B Golapbag under Zatrabari Thana. Thereafter the said Pistol was recovered on 28.04.2013 at 9.30 a.m. from a table of the said office, and it appears from the License that only 50 bullets to be kept but the accused violating condition kept 98 round bullets with 4 Magzine in his custody. The accused failed to give satisfactory reply for keeping execess bullets and Magzine. Thereafter, a seizure list was prepared there at 10.10 a.m. on 28.04.2013 and took signature of the witnesses.  The accused violating term and condition of license illegally kept excess 48 round bullets and 4 Magzine and thus committed offence under section 21/23 of the Arms Act, 1878. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">3.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">After completion of investigation the police submitted the charge sheet against accused-appellant under section 21 and 23 of the Arms Act, 1878.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">4.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The accused-appellant was put on trial before the Metropolitan Special Tribunal No.6, Dhaka to answer the charge against him under section 21 and 23 of the Arms Act, 1878 to which he pleaded not guilty and claimed to be tried. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">At the trial the prosecution has examined as many as 6(six) witnesses while the defence examined none but cross-examined all the prosecution witnesses. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The defence case as it transpires from the trend of the cross-examination is that the accused-appellant was innocent and his license and bullets were in accordance with law and he was innocent. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">On conclusion of the trial the learned Judge of the Tribunal by the impugned judgment found the accused-appellant guilty of the offence under section 21 and 23 of the Arms Act, 1878 and sentenced him as stated above. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Being aggrieved by and dissatisfied with the impugned judgment and order of conviction and sentence the accused-appellant preferred the instant appeal. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 112%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 112%;">9.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 112%;">Mr. Abul Kalam Mainuddin, the learned Advocate appearing for the accused-appellant has placed the memo of appeal, F.I.R., charge sheet, evidence on record and judgment of the court below and submits that the prosecution has failed to prove the charge against the <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">accused-appellant by adducing any independent</span> and neutral witness. He submits that the trial court failed to consider that the accused-appellant is entitled to keep 100 pieces of bullets as per provisions of section 24 of the Bangal Arms Act Manual 1924. He lastly <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">submits that the accused-appellant did not violate</span> <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">any term and condition of his license and as such</span> impugned judgment and order of conviction and sentence is not sustainable in law. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 112%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 112%;">10.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 112%;">Mr. Shafiul Bashar Bhandary, the learned Deputy Attorney General appearing for the State submits that the learned Judge of the trial court assessing the evidence and materials on record rightly found the accused-appellant guilty and sentenced him accordingly and therefore he prayed for dismissed the appeal. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong></span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">The District Magistrate may at his discretion allow any reasonable quantity in excess of the limit prescribed to a person who can prove that he needs more ammunition.</span> </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">29.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">From a combined reading of the above provisions of law, I find a clear proposition of law that the maximum amount of ammunition can be possessed during the year by the holder of a licences of Revolver and Pistol, 100 rounds bullets. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">30.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The strict requirement of law is that onus lies on the prosecution to prove its case beyond all reasonable doubt. The learned Judge of the Special Tribunal failed to consider the above provisions of law that the accused-appellant is entitled to purchase 50 pieces of bullets at a time and keep in his custody maximum 100 pieces of bullets. In the instant case the prosecution has found 98 pieces of bullets in the possession of the accused-appellant which is not violation of provision of law under section 21 of the Arms Act 1878 and as such the learned Judge of the Special Tribunal passed the impugned judgment and order of conviction is not sustainable in law. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">31.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In view of the above, I find merit in the appeal. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">32.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In the result, the appeal is allowed. The impugned judgment and order of conviction of sentence dated </span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">18.11.2015 passed by the learned Metropolitan Special Tribunal No.6, Dhaka in Metropolitan Special Tribunal Case No. 300 of 2013 corresponding to G.R. Case No. 368 of 2013 arising out of Zatrabari Police Station Case No. 98 dated 28.04.2013 is hereby set aside. The accused-appellant namely Saifuddin Murad be set at liberty at once, if not wanted in connection with any other case. The sureties are discharged from their respective bail bonds.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Let the Lower Court Records along with a copy of this judgment be sent to the Court below at-once.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Ed. </span></strong></span></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title=""><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10pt;">Criminal </span></strong></a><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10pt;">Appeal No. 10074 of 2015</span></strong></span></p></div></div></div></div>

line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 10pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.6pt;"> </span></strong></span></p><p> </p><div align="center"><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="MsoNormalTable" style="margin-left: 5.4pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">And</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in .25in -5.75pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">J.
